prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We focus on the continuum emission in this science goal, and thus select the maximum bandwidth in the correlator setting. We select the sky frequency of 152 GHz so that the best frequency ranges in atmospheric transmission can be covered.

The purpose of this observation is to image ring-like gaps at ~ 20 AU (~ 0.4") and ~ 80 AU (~ 1.5") form the central star, whose gap widths are approximately 15 - 20 AU (0.28" - 0.37") (Debes et al. 2013; Akiyama et al. 2015). Therefore, We observe the disk with angular resolution of 0.2". The source size was esitmated to be 1.06" x 1.04" by CO (J=2-1) emission (Isella et al. 2009). Thus, we set 1.1" as largest angular scale for the source in this observation.
Since our previous near-IR observation by Subaru telescope has the inner working angle of 0.2", we can approach the same inner region of the disk as the near-IR observation and test the spatial coincidence/anti-coincidence of the millimeter and NIR disk structure.

The science goal is to obtain the dust continuum image of the disk around TW Hya at band 4. Previous near-IR observations by HST and Subaru telescope shows two ring-like gaps at approximately 20 and 80 AU from the central star. We select beam size of 0.2" that is the same minimum inner working angle of previous near-IR observations to trace the same inner part of the disk with near-IR observation.
Since TW Hya has been extensively observed by mm/sub-mm wavelengths, resulting in a number of continuum images at different wavelenghts, we estimate continuum emission at 145 GHz by interpolating 20 mJy/beam at 230 GHz (corresponding to band 6) obtained by CARMA (Isella et al. 2009) and 9 mJy at 89 GHz (corresponding to band 3) available in ALMA science verification database. As a result, the expected peak continuum emission is approximately 9 mJy/beam after considering beam size. We want 20 sigma detection so that we can discuss the presence of large grains in the ring-like gap as described in the science justification. Thus, we request 0.45 mJy/beam for the desired sensitivity per pointing.

We focus on the continuum emission in this science goal, and thus select the maximum bandwidth in the correlator setting. We select the sky frequency of 233 GHz so that the best frequency ranges in atmospheric transmission can be covered.

The purpose of this observation is to image ring-like gaps at ~ 20 AU (~ 0.4") and ~ 80 AU (~ 1.5") form the central star, whose gap widths are approximately 15 - 20 AU (0.28" - 0.37") (Debes et al. 2013; Akiyama et al. 2015). Therefore, We observe the disk with angular resolution of 0.2". The source size was esitmated to be 1.06" x 1.04" by CO (J=2-1) emission (Isella et al. 2009). Thus, we set 1.1" as largest angular scale for the source in this observation.
Since our previous near-IR observation by Subaru telescope has the inner working angle of 0.2", we can approach the same inner region of the disk as the near-IR observation and test the spatial coincidence/anti-coincidence of the millimeter and NIR disk structure.

The science goal is to obtain the dust continuum image of the disk around TW Hya at band 6. Previous near-IR observations by HST and Subaru telescope shows two ring-like gaps at approximately 20 and 80 AU from the central star. We select beam size of 0.2" that is the same minimum inner working angle of previous near-IR observations to trace the same inner part of the disk with near-IR observation.
Since TW Hya has been extensively observed by mm/sub-mm wavelengths, resulting in a number of continuum images at different wavelenghts, TW Hya have been extensively observed and basic properties are given in the literatures. We estimate continuum emission at the sky frequency of 221 GHz based on the CARMA result at 230 GHz (Table 3 in Isella et al. 2009). As a result, estimated peak continuum flux density is 20 mJy/beam. We want 20 sigma detection so that we can discuss the presence of large grains in the ring-like gap as described in the science justification. Thus, we request 1 mJy/beam for the desired sensitivity per pointing.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: band7 CO & cont
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: 13CO(J=3-2), C18O(J=3-2), and continuum observation at 350 GHz.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: Since TW Hya has a line width of 1 km/s (Hughes et al. 2011), we select velocity resolution of 0.26 km/s after spectral averaging by a facor of 2, providing 4 channels per line width. The spectral averaging is applied rather than selecting the wider bandwidth because the velocity gradient in a beam might be significant.

The purpose of this observation is to image ring-like gaps at ~ 20 AU (~ 0.4") and ~ 80 AU (~ 1.5") form the central star, whose widths are approximately 15 - 20 AU (0.28" - 0.37") (Debes et al. 2013; Akiyama et al. 2015). The source size was esitmated to be 1.06" x 1.04" by CO (J=2-1) emission (Isella et al. 2009). Taking account of errors, we set 1.5", slightly larger scale than the source size as largest angular scale for the source in this observation. Since our previous near-IR observation by Subaru telescope has the inner working angle of 0.2", we can approach the same inner region of the disk as the near-IR observation and directly compare the near-IR and ALMA images.

The science goal is to obtain gas and dust continuum image of the disk around TW Hya. Previous near-IR observations by HST and Subaru telescope shows two ring-like gaps at approximately 20 and 80 AU from the central star. We select beam size of 0.2" that is the same minimum inner working angle of previous near-IR observations to trace the same near-IR observation region including inner part of the disk.
TW Hya have been extensively observed and basic properties are given in the literatures. We estimate continuum emission at the sky frequency of 320 GHz based on the SMA result at 344.4 GHz (Andrews et al. 2012). As a result, estimated peak continuum flux density is 29.7 mJy/beam after considering beam size. We want 20 sigma detection so that we can discuss the presence of large grains in the ring-like gap as described in the science justification. Thus, we request 1.5 mJy/beam for the desired sensitivity per pointing.
We also select 13CO(J=3-2) and C18O(J=3-2) for confining the origin of the gap as described in the science justification. Since TW Hya has a line width of approximately 1 km/s (Hughes et al. 2011), we select 937.5 MHz bandwidth to have the velocity resolution of 0.26 km/s after spectral averaging, so that we can differentiate gas motion from the Keplerian motion within 100 AU.

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract: A number of observational signatures of planet formation have been observed in protoplanetary disks around low and intermediate mass YSOs at optical, infrared, and mm/sub-mm wavelengths. Recently multiple ring-like gaps have been discovered in the disk around TW Hydrae by near-IR observations, implying that multiple planets are forming as a planetary system. The purpose of this observation is to obtain spatially resolved image of the disk by continuum emission at several frequencies and gas in order to confine the origin of the multiple gap. Since it is necessary to probe dust and gas distribution in the disk interior in the inner region of the disk (20 and 80 AU), we propose dust continuum, 13CO(J=3-2), and C18(J=3-2) observations with 0.2" in spatial resolution, which cansufficiently resolve the disk gaps. The proposed observation will make clear whether or not disk material exists in the gaps and dust size or the scale height at the gaps is constant with those in the other regions. The origin of the ring-like gap will become more conclusive by the combination of ALMA data and the existing NIR/optical imagery.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:scientificCategoryString: Circumstellar disks, exoplanets and the solar system
